bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Austin Smith, December 12, 1952

div1.p: Hench has returned from the dedication ceremony of Camp Lazear and offers to send Smith clippings and photographs of the dedication.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Austin Smith, December 12, 1952
div1.opener:
December 12, 1952
Dr. Austin Smith, Editor
Journal of the American Medical Association
535 North Dearborn
Chicago 10, Illinois
My dear Doctor Smith:
div1.p:
I returned from Cuba Sunday night after a very pleasant trip. I have
your letter of December 8 requesting information regarding the dedica-
tion. I appreciate very much your interest and fill bure that the Cubans
do too.

I can do one of two things. I can send you now a number of clippings, three
or four from the Havana Post, published in English, and a half dozen or more
published in Spanish and can, within a very few days, send you some glossy
prints taken at the ceremony in case you should want to publish one or two.
From the above, you can write your own story.

Or, if you prefer to have me write up the affair (as if, perhaps, I were
your Havana correspondent), I will do so but I cannot do it until after Christ-
mas or New Year's. I am trying very hard to finish a chapter on cortisone
which was due November 1. This will take every moment of my time between
now and Christmas. I have promised the Clinic to write up the story of the
Camp Lazear dedication and present it at staff shortly after New Year's
under andban heading as “Camp Lazear near Havana - a New Medical Shrine”
or something like that. Let me know your wishes.

The affair was really very nice and represents a very fine beginning,
something upon which we can build steadily.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
P.S.: Your A.M.A. representative arrived at the very last second of the
last minute. Not having received his name from Doctor Lull, I had no cer-
tainty of his arrival. I felt it was so important that the A.M.A. be rep-
resented that, in view of the letters of yourself and Doctor Lull to me, I
went ahead and bought a wreath and had asked Ambassador Beaulac to lay it
but at the last minute, Doctor Chrisman of Miami arrived and laid the first
wreath. He and his wife were charming people and I was delighted to meet
them.
